title: Segal's 2006 Dovev Single Vineyard Kosher Argaman (Galil)

description: A bit hard and dark at first, yet despite rubbery, leathery aromas this evolves into a fine everyday Malbec. The palate hits with punch and pop; it's jumpy and packed with boysenberry, blueberry and blackberry flavors. A fruit bomb for sure, but one with balance and New World intensity that many people are looking for.
title: Santa Rita 2009 Reserva Malbec (Colchagua Valley)

description: Good and dry, with rugged, dusty tannins and fine varietal flavors. Shows real elegance and class, with cherry, red currant, cedar and spice flavors. Drink now–2013.
title: Sean Minor 2008 4B Merlot (Napa Valley)

description: Terra Rossa Riserva shows structure, concentration and chewy fruit flavors that last long on the finish. This is the kind of wine you'll want to pair with succulent steak or pork chops on an open grill.
title: Tenuta di Trecciano 2007 Terra Rossa Riserva  (Chianti Colli Senesi)

description: This Riserva Chianti Classico is exactly the kind of wine you'll want to pair with grilled sausage and white beans or lamb chops with rosemary marinade. It offers bright fruit tones backed by crisp acidity and medium structure.
title: Tenuta di Vignole 2006 Riserva Vìgnole  (Chianti Classico)

description: Soft, ripe fruit, already accessible. This has a generous feel and flavors of berries and red plums. Not a wine for aging, but very attractive.
title: CARM 2008 Vintage  (Port)

description: Fine, fresh white Bordeaux from this Entre-deux-Mers property. A blend of Sauvignon Blanc and Sémillon, just touched by wood, with spice and melon flavors brightened by citrus.
title: Château Thieuley 2008  Bordeaux Blanc

description: An unexpected touch of caramel butterscotch or candied fruit could indicate very mild oxidation although the jury is still out. Otherwise, the wine does a good job of presenting austere aromas of old spice, worn leather and dried fruit.
title: Ciacci Piccolomini d'Aragona 2006  Brunello di Montalcino

description: Well balanced wine, the entry level of the Conceito range. It has lively acidity and red cherry and strawberry fruits packed with underlying tannins. It is a fresh wine, showing the lighter side of the Douro, while retaining great minerality.
title: Conceito Vinhos 2008 Contraste Red (Douro)

description: Il Palazzone offers a compact, streamlined interpretation of Brunello with a bright ruby color and crispness that helps keep the palate refreshed sip after sip. It offers lingering tones of black licorice, cola, mature fruit, cassis and dried raspberry.
title: Il Palazzone 2006  Brunello di Montalcino

description: Bone dry and complex, with terroir-infused mineral, citrus, pear and sweet green mint flavors. A streamlined, layered wine, although it's just a bit hot in alcohol.
title: Kessler-Haak 2009 Kessler-Haak Vineyard Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

description: A good, strong, sturdy wine, filled with classic blackberry, black currant and cassis flavors. It's dry and rich, but the tannins are aggressive. They're edgy and tough and off-putting. It may be the kind of old-fashioned wine that comes around after 10 or 15 years.
title: Markham 2007 The Philanthropist Yountville Estate Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

description: Campidonne is a sassy, spicy wine with loads of cinnamon, chocolate, nutmeg and spice spread over a core of black fruit and cherry. It's smooth and compact with a bright spot of freshness on the medium finish.
title: Pietrafitta NV Campidonne Sangiovese (Toscana)

description: Here's an impressive newcomer to the Montecucco (coastal Tuscany) wine scene. Thanks to abundant sunshine and fertile soils, this Sangiovese is thickly structured and enhanced by mature berry aromas and a playful touch of sour cherry.
title: Pieve Vecchia 2007 Chorum  (Montecucco)

description: Villa Pillo is an expert at producing value wines and this Cabernet Franc-Merlot is no exception. The wine boasts measured renderings of blueberry, coffee, almond and chocolate.
title: Villa Pillo 2006 Cingalino Red (Toscana)

description: Braccale is a drinkable, food-friendly wine. That's because this wine's naturally tempered elegance means it won't overpower what you eat. It delivers aromas of sweet red fruit, toasted nuts and has a crisp, spice-driven finish.
title: Jacopo Biondi-Santi 2005 Braccale  (Maremma)

description: Inky dark, with deep berry, sandalwood and sawmill aromas. Color and potency are not lacking in this modern-styled Tempranillo, which hits like a hammer. Feelwise, this is a tough, angular wine that will benefit from another year or two of aging. Now it's very tight and tannic, with piercing acidity.
title: Marqués de Cáceres 2005 MC  (Rioja)

description: Superripe, such that it's medicinal and pruny. The nose reeks of reduced blueberry and cassis, while the palate is soft, low in acidity and full of ripe, dark raisin, prune and spice cake flavors. If you like a dense wine, this is it. But expect it to be Port-like and on the liqueur-ish side. Drink now.
title: Marques de Griñon 2003 Estate Bottled Petit Verdot (Dominio de Valdepusa)

description: This is a lithe, sinewy wine, powerful yet lean, with coiled intensity to its crisp citrus and mineral flavors. It finishes long and tart, with the bracing acids suggestive of a long evolution. Hold 3–5 years and see if it blossoms.
title: Maximin Grünhäuser 2005 Abtsberg Superior Riesling (Mosel-Saar-Ruwer)

description: Fresh and perfumed, this wine offers great citric flavors, a lively crispness rare in white wines from central Portugal. Pear and some yellow fruits give roundness.
title: Quinta da Alorna 2006 White (Ribatejo)

description: Exciting, fresh and full of spicy, toasted undertones, this wine immediately calls for a food pairing of a richer seafood (think oysters, crab) or poultry. The flavors are balanced and buoyed by crispness, but the wine still offers complexity and a lingering finish.
title: Lamoreaux Landing 2006 Estate Bottled Reserve Chardonnay (Finger Lakes)

description: The winery's Saralee's bottling has been variable over the years. The '06 is tasty and eminently drinkable if you want a nice, dry, crisp Pinot. It's pale in color, silky in the mouth, and direct in cherry, cola, spice and oaky flavors. Drink now.
title: Lost Canyon 2006 Saralee's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

description: Here's a nice, smooth-drinking red wine that's rich enough to serve with your best fare. The balance is nice, with crisp acids and tannins framing cherry, red currant and mocha flavors. Try this medium-bodied wine as an alternative to Cabernet or Merlot.
title: Madroña 2004 Malbec (El Dorado)

description: Sangiovese with 25% Merlot for added softness and dimension, this wine boasts pretty notes of cherry, blue flowers, toasted almonds and exotic spice. It has nice elegance overall but is a bit compact in the mouth.
title: Mazzei 2004 Poggio alla Badiola Sangiovese (Toscana)

description: Draws you in with its brilliant ruby color and assertive bouquet of dark plum, black cherry and berry nuanced with menthol and dirt. A full, round mouthfeel and soft, fleeting tannins showcase the wine's solid balance, and the strong finish is not sweet or overdone.
title: Psagot 2004 Kosher Merlot (Judean Hills)

description: When this hilly vineyard Cab first came out, it was very good, but quality has slipped over the years. The '04 is perfectly decent in oak-infused blackberry and currant flavors and rich tannins, and it may even improve for a few years.
title: Simi 2004 Landslide Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

description: On the dry side, this medium-bodied kabinett clocks in at 11% alcohol but seems balanced anyway, with peach and pear aromas and flavors given complexity through notes of smoke, clover blossom and mint. Crisp and refreshing on the finish.
title: Gunderloch 2006 Jean-Baptiste Kabinett Riesling (Rheinhessen)

description: An obscure Catalonian wine made from indigenous grapes, this pricey oddball starts with bubblegum and candy aromas mixed with smoke and meat. The color is dark and the wine is a bit rough. But in a country, unusual way it redeems itself with zippy cherry flavors and a fresh, tight mouthfeel. Best with food.
title: Heretat Montrubí 2004 Gaintus Red (Vino de Mesa)

description: Fans of Barbera will find the hard acids and thick tannins they love in this rustic Italian variety. The flavors are all dry: dried blackberries and cherries, dried leather, cured tobacco leaf, beef jerky, star anise. Yet there's a fruity sweetness that's charming. Great with almost anything starring sausage.
title: Montevina 2005 Terra d'Oro Barbera (Amador County)

description: Le Sughere is a well-composed wine, except for a hint of Band-Aid that blows off relatively quickly to enhance natural aromas of red fruit, root beer and toast. It offers sweet herb flavors and fresh mint on the close.
title: Rocca di Frassinello 2005 Le Sughere di Frassinello  (Maremma)

description: This is soft, fruity and very approachable, with flavors of strawberry jam. Highlights of sassafras and a pleasing spiciness add texture and interest.
title: Stoller 2005 Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

description: This is a Cab-based Bordeaux blend, and it shows Paso's ability to produce a ripe, gentle red wine that's immediately appealing. There's a nice earthiness to the cassis flavors, and a rich, tannic structure that makes you dream of a perfectly broiled steak or chop, brushed with brown butter sauce with a touch of garlic.
title: Sylvester 2005 Nikiara Red (Paso Robles)

description: Earthy, like some Napa Chards, with a sage and thyme edge to the pear and peach fruit. The wine also is a little soft. But there's an interesting minerality. Could develop bottle complexity over the next few years.
title: Testarossa 2006 Brosseau Vineyard Chardonnay (Chalone)

description: This small production (200 cases) Pinot Noir is a mix of older and younger estate vines, a selection of lots given 22 months in 60 and 132 gallon French oak casks. It's still tasting quite young, sharp and chewy, with spicy fruit backed up against earthy tannins. Give it plenty of breathing time.
title: David Hill 2005 Estate Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

description: Tart and forward, with cranberry and raspberry fruit front and center, this is a tasty, acidic and lightly spicy effort that shows some nice precision. It's not a big wine, but balanced and based upon sharp acids that carry the fruit and cut through the finish.
title: Duck Pond 2006 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

description: Nothing subtle about this big, ripe, oaky Chardonnay. It shows the tropical fruit richness of a fine Alexander Valley Chard, flamboyant in pineapple custard flavor, with a flinty minerality. The sweet overlay of smoky oak is perfectly in keeping with the wine's volume.
title: Dutcher Crossing 2006 Stuhlmuller Vineyard Chardonnay (Alexander Valley)

description: Winemaker Nick Goldschmidt has turned out a Shiraz that seems a bit conflicted. It's only medium-bodied, yet packs in overripe flavors of cooked berries laced with dark chocolate and espresso. The peppery notes on the finish give it enough verve to pair with steaks or burgers.
title: Forefathers 2005 Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

description: Fast becoming one of the hallmark blends of Portugal, this 50-50 mix of Aragonez and Touriga Nacional is a seriously structured wine, with great wild fruit and mushroom flavors alongside dark, dry tannins. The acidity is very definite. A good food wine.
title: Adega Cooperativa de Borba 2006 Aragonez and Touriga Nacional Red (Alentejano)
